thread.title: Missing teen found in Tangipahoa Parish; former Jennings resident arrested
thread.title_full: Missing teen found in Tangipahoa Parish; former Jennings resident arrested

author: Matt Phillips
title: Missing teen found in Tangipahoa Parish; former Jennings resident arrested
text:
TANGIPAHOA PARISH, La. (KPLC) - A former Jennings resident is accused of bringing a 14-year-old runaway from Tennessee to Louisiana and having sex with her.
The girl has been found safe and Alexander Materne, 28, of St. Rose, Louisiana has been arrested.
Andrew Materne, 28, is accused of taking a 14-year-old runaway from her home in Tennessee to his home in Louisiana. (Tangipahoa Parish Sheriff's Office) According to a news release from the St. Charles Parish Sheriff’s Office , Materne met the girl while playing an online game, and made arrangements to pick her up from her home in Tennessee so she could stay with him.
On Dec. 23, the sheriff’s office said Materne brought the girl to his home in St. Rose and engaged in sexual acts. The sheriff’s office said the girl then disclosed her age to Materne.
After some time, Materne brought the girl to a secluded, wooded area in Tangipahoa Parish and left her with a tent, food, and water, the St. Charles Parish Sheriff’s Office said. Materne then went to Jennings to celebrate Christmas with his family.
On Christmas Eve, Jennings Police Chief Danny Semmes said his office received a call about Materne possibly having the girl in Jennings. However, when police went to check at the family home in Jennings, they were told he no longer lived there.
Semmes said that on Christmas morning, Jennings police were told Materne had returned to the family home and later made contact with him.
According to Jennings police , Materne told authorities he picked the girl up from her home in Tennessee and brought her to his home in St. Rose. Materne said he had sex with the girl before bringing her to the wooded area in Tangipahoa Parish, where she remained for about two days.
Semmes said Materne agreed to show investigators where the girl was, leading them to a tent in the woods 42 miles from his home.
The girl was found safe, taken to a hospital, and returned to her family, authorities said.
Materne was booked into the Tangipahoa Parish Jail for the following charges:
Aggravated kidnapping of a child Contributing to the delinquency of a juvenile Materne also faces arrest warrants for felony counts of human trafficking and carnal knowledge. According to the St. Charles Parish Sheriff’s Office, Materne will be booked into the parish jail once he can be transported.
